overview_summary: None of the five adjacent landowners have a documented public stance regarding the development, with all classified as "unknown" in the absence of any stated support or opposition. Their community influence appears limited — none hold public office or leadership roles, and only one family (the Stoeltings) has notable long-term local ties that might confer moderate social influence.

neighbors.name: Beau Martin & Jessica Martin
neighbors.claims: Beau Martin is an Orleans-area farmer who received about $46,691 in USDA farm subsidies from 1995 to 2024 [EWG Farm Subsidy Database](https://farm.ewg.org/addrsearch.php?page=3&z=1&zip=68966). No records were found of Beau or Jessica Martin speaking in local meetings or media about land development or energy projects (no mentions in county board minutes or news archives as of retrieval).

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out farmer-to-farmer emphasizing respect for their farming operations and minimal impact on their land use. A project representative with an agricultural background could build rapport and address any farmland preservation concerns.

neighbors.name: Carol A. Wells
neighbors.claims: Carol A. Wells was an absentee landowner who lived in Grand Island and passed away in October 2021 at age 88 [Grand Island Independent](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/theindependent/name/carol-wells-obituary?id=31285892). She and her husband maintained their primary residence outside Harlan County, and there is no indication of her direct involvement in local civic affairs or development discussions (her presence in the Orleans area was limited to property ownership).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through her estate or surviving family, focusing on maintaining the land’s value and ensuring the project does not create burdens for them. Communication should emphasize low impact on the property and stable long-term stewardship.

neighbors.name: Bart A. Woodward & Jill R. Woodward
neighbors.claims: Bart A. Woodward and Jill R. Woodward are listed as landowners in the Orleans vicinity, though they have no public profile in available records (no news articles or meeting minutes name them in connection with community issues as of the latest search). They appear to be private farmers or landowners in Harlan County, with no documented leadership positions or public statements on local development or energy projects.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Woodwards through informal, neighborly contact—perhaps via mutual farming acquaintances—to share information. Emphasize respect for rural lifestyle and clarify how the project addresses practical concerns like access roads and land preservation.

neighbors.name: Jesse R. Hays & Jill C. Hays
neighbors.claims: Jesse R. Hays is an Orleans-area resident who held a Nebraska contractor’s license (No. 19341) with a listed address on H Road near Orleans [BuildZoom](https://www.buildzoom.com/contractor/jesse-hays). This suggests he operates a local contracting or construction business, but there are no public records of the Hays couple taking positions on development or participating in county meetings related to land use. They have not been cited in news or public forums regarding energy or infrastructure projects in the community.

approach_recommendations.engage: Highlight potential benefits to the local economy and opportunities for local contractors when communicating with the Hays household. Having a project manager discuss how the development might create local jobs or contracts can align with Jesse Hays’s professional interests.

neighbors.name: Gary L. Stoelting & James G. Stoelting
neighbors.claims: Gary L. Stoelting and James G. Stoelting are part of a long-standing farm family in the Orleans area. A family member, John A. Stoelting, was noted as “formerly of Orleans” in his obituary, reflecting the family’s deep roots in the community [Kearney Hub](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/kearneyhub/name/john-stoelting-obituary?id=53587968). The Stoelting Farms operation has a presence in Harlan County (appearing in USDA program listings) ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=31083&page=1&progcode=tot_lvstfo&yr=2024#:~:text=35%20%20,%24652)), indicating they are active in agriculture. They have not publicly voiced opinions on local development in available records, but their multi-generational tenure suggests they hold informal influence and strong attachment to the land.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Stoeltings with respect for their family’s legacy in the area. It may be effective to involve a respected local agricultural figure or neighbor in discussions, emphasizing how the project can coexist with farming traditions and safeguard the land for future generations.
